item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: October 17
item.description: Viktor Orban, prime minister of Hungary, is on a state visit to India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Viktor Orban, prime minister of Hungary, inspecting a guard of honor during a ceremonial reception at Rashtrapati Bhavan, India's presidential palace, in New Delhi. Mr. Orban is on a state visit to India.

item.title: At War Blog: Insight Into How Insurgents Fought in Iraq
item.description: Documents obtained known as “storyboards” shed light on how American soldiers discovered weapons caches and where they came from.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ISMAY

item.title: Lens Blog: Brazil’s Protests, on and Off the Wall
item.description: In busy São Paulo, where people stop for little, a photo collective puts images of the demonstrations that rocked Brazil in public spaces, inviting reflection.
item.dc:creator: By JILL LANGLOIS

item.title: Letter From Europe: As They Leave Afghanistan, Britons Ask, ‘Why?’
item.description: British troops, like their American counterparts, are preparing to leave Afghanistan after a tenure that appears to have achieved few of the goals set by their political masters.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: As Public Monuments Crumble, Private Aid Seen as Possible Savior
item.description: Restoration of the 16th-century Humayun’s Tomb in Delhi by private agencies offers a possible model for preservation of other derelict monuments in India.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: A view of the Humayun's Tomb in New Delhi on Sept. 18.

item.title: Latin America Brings Up Its Dead, Seeking Truth to Help Settle the Past
item.description: Exhuming the remains of the notable dead has become increasingly common in Latin American countries. Brazil, the latest, plans to exhume a former civilian president to investigate assassination claims.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers transported the coffin of former President Salvador Allende of Chile for exhumation in 2011.

item.title: Syrian Official Says Peace Talks Could Resume Nov. 23
item.description: The announcement from a deputy prime minister raised speculation about who would attend and who would represent the fractured opposition.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Japan’s Leader Rejects Visit to War Shrine
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe refused calls to visit a controversial Tokyo war shrine, in an apparent effort to avoid angering Asian neighbors including China.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Mayor of Chinese City Is Held by Communist Party Investigators
item.description: The mayor of Nanjing, Ji Jianye, who cast his city as modern and progressive, is accused of “grave disciplinary violations,” according to Chinese state-run news media.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: A Syrian Refugee Family’s New Life
item.description: Millions of Syrians have fled the civil war, scattering to neighboring countries like Jordan. Many have dreams of returning to a homeland long vanished.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Suicide Bomber in Pakistan Kills a Provincial Official
item.description: The attack, which came as the official was entertaining visitors, was the most high-profile political assassination in Pakistan this year.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Bruno Metsu, Coach Who Took Senegal on World Cup Run, Dies at 59
item.description: Metsu, a Frenchman, was a midfielder on European teams for nearly two decades, but he achieved his biggest success working in Africa.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK
item.media:description: Bruno Metsu shown in 2008 when he was the coach of the United Arab Emirates team.

item.title: Q. and A.: Examining the Status of Iran’s Nuclear Program and Talks
item.description: Key questions about the country’s nuclear abilities and what was accomplished in the last round of negotiations are answered.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, widely seen as a pragmatist, played a key role in Iran’s voluntary suspension of uranium enrichment in 2004, which Western powers responded to by asking for more concessions from Iran.

item.title: As Secession Talk Swells in Catalonia, Business Leaders Remain Wary of Costs
item.description: Catalan businesspeople worry less about what Madrid owes the region and more about whether political instability could hamper Spain’s prospects of returning to precrisis growth levels.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Arnau Bach for The New York Times
item.media:description: José Luis Bonet Ferrer, president of Freixenet, the major sparkling wine producer in Catalonia, Spain, expresses concern about economic blowback from the Catalan independence movement.

item.title: Disposal of Chemical Arms in Syria Progresses
item.description: Chemical weapons inspectors have reached 11 of Syria’s 20 sites and have begun destroying equipment at 6 of them, officials said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Many Dead or Missing After Typhoon
item.description: A powerful typhoon struck eastern Japan on Wednesday, causing landslides and floods that left at least 17 people dead and 43 missing, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Group Reports New Deadly Attacks
item.description: A new wave of attacks and killings has engulfed parts of the Central African Republic, Doctors Without Borders reported Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: No Solution on Burial of Ex-Nazi
item.description: After protests halted the funeral of the former Nazi Erich Priebke, who was associated with a World War II massacre, the question of how to dispose of his remains was unresolved.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Trial Opens for Imelda Marcos’s Ex-Aide
item.description: An ex-aide to Imelda Marcos, former first lady of the Philippines, is being tried for conspiring to sell valuable paintings that were bought by Mrs. Marcos with state money.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

item.title: Snowden Journalist’s New Venture to Be Bankrolled by eBay Founder
item.description: Pierre Omidyar will finance the news site drawing Glenn Greenwald away from The Guardian, where he reported on the revelations by Edward Snowden.
item.dc:creator: By NOAM COHEN and QUENTIN HARDY
item.media:description: Pierre M. Omidyar, the founder of eBay, will join with Glenn Greenwald and others to create a news site from the ground up.

item.title: Effort to Evacuate Syrian Civilians Is Thwarted by Shelling
item.description: The abortive evacuation was arranged in a small-scale local deal that some aid workers and others had hoped could become a blueprint for building trust.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Assault of Dutch Diplomat in Moscow Frays Ties Between Russia and the Netherlands
item.description: The Russian Foreign Ministry tried to head off any political fallout from the attack in the diplomat’s apartment by promising to detain the two assailants.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: A computer screen showing a photo of Onno Elderenbosch, the Netherlands’ deputy ambassador to Russia, who was beaten up in his apartment in Moscow.

item.title: After Talks on Iran’s Nuclear Program, Officials Highlight the Positive
item.description: In a statement, Iran and six world powers described the two days of discussions in Geneva as “forward looking” but did not disclose details.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, took part in a rare joint statement.

item.title: British Police on Defensive Over Downing Street Clash
item.description: A year after a minister was forced to quit the cabinet over an altercation with the police, new evidence has cast doubt on the police’s account.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: The Lede: Body of Nazi War Criminal Moved to Airport in Rome After Clashes
item.description: The body of a notorious Nazi commander, who orchestrated the killing of 335 Italian civilians seven decades ago, was moved to a military airport on Wednesday.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
